biblStruct.note: FIAN/TD/1-03 Free Field Dynamics in the Generalized AdS (Super)Space

abstract.p: Pure gauge representation for general vacuum background fields (Cartan forms) in the generalized AdS superspace identified with OSp(L, M) is found. This allows us to formulate dynamics of free massless fields in the generalized AdS space-time and to find their (generalized) conformal and higher spin field transformation laws. Generic solution of the field equations is also constructed explicitly. The results are obtained with the aid of the star product realization of ortosymplectic superalgebras.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In the recent papers [1, 2] it was shown that infinite multiplets of massless higher spins in 4d flat Minkowski space-time admit description in terms of ten-dimensional space-time M 4 with real symmetric bispinor matrix coordinates X αβ = X βα , (α, β = 1 . . . 4). A single scalar field c(X) in M 4 describes massless fields of all integer spins in 4d Minkowski space-time upon imposing field equations found in [1]. Half-integer spin massless fields are described analogously by a spinor field c α (X). That massless fields of all spins have to admit some formulation in M 4 was argued by Fronsdal in the pioneering paper [3] where it was also stressed that such infinite sets of massless fields have to form representations of the extension of the 4d conformal group su(2, 2) to sp(8|R). Then in [4] it was found that world-line particle models based on sp(8) give rise to massless higher spin excitations of all spins. The explicit realization of the sp(8) symmetry by local transformations was given in [1] as well as the generalization of the proposed sp(8) covariant dynamical equations to M M with arbitrary even M.

The Poincare subalgebra is spanned by L mn and P m . K m and D are the generators of special conformal transformations and dilatations, respectively. To embed the AdS d algebra o(d − 1, 2) into the d-dimensional conformal algebra o(d, 2) one identifies the AdS d translations with the mixture of translations and special conformal transformations in the conformal algebra

figure.trash: P a AdS d = P a − λ 2 K a . (1.3) The generators P a AdS d

div.p: and L ab form the AdS d subalgebra o(d − 1, 2) ⊂ o(d, 2). This embedding breaks down the manifest o(1, 1) dilatation covariance because it mixes the operators P a and K a , which have different dimensions. λ is the dimensionful Wigner- Inönu contraction parameter to be identified with the inverse AdS d radius. The sp(2M) algebra admits analogous description in terms of the generators L α β , P αβ , K αβ and D, where indices α, β . . . range from 1 to M and L α β is traceless. The commutation relations are [K αβ , K γδ ] = 0 , [P αβ , P γδ ] = 0 ,

figure.trash: (1.4) [D, P αβ ] = −P αβ , [D, K αβ ] = K αβ , [D, L α β ] = 0 , (1.5) [L α β , P γδ ] = −δ γ β P αδ − δ δ β P αγ + 2 M δ α β P γδ , (1.6) [L α β , K γδ ] = δ α γ K βδ + δ α δ K βγ − 2 M δ α β K γδ , (1.7) [P αβ , K γδ ] = L α δ δ β γ + L β δ δ α γ + L α γ δ β δ + L β γ δ α δ + 4 M D(δ α δ δ β γ + δ β δ δ α γ ) , (1.8) [L α β , L γ δ ] = δ α δ L γ β − δ γ β L α δ . (1.9)

div.p: Note that the generalized Lorentz subalgebra generated by L α β is sl M . Analogously to the usual conformal algebra, generalized translations generated by P αβ form Abelian subalgebra of sp(2M). Generalized special conformal transformations generate a dual Abelian subalgebra. The commutation relations (1.4)-(1.9) can be realized by the vector fields

figure.trash: P αβ = ∂ ∂X αβ , K αβ = 4X αγ X βη ∂ ∂X γη , (1.10) L α β = 2X βγ ∂ ∂X αγ − 2 M δ α β X βγ ∂ ∂X βγ , D = X βγ ∂ ∂X βγ , (1.11) where X αβ = X βα are coordinates of M M .

div.p: The simplest way to see that the commutation relations (1.4)-(1.9) are indeed of sp(2M) is to use its oscillator realization [7]. Actually, let a α and b α be oscillators with the commutation relations

figure.trash: [ˆ a α , ˆ b β ] = δ α β , [ˆ a α , ˆ a β ] = 0 , [ ˆ b α , ˆ b β ] = 0 . (1.12) The generators of sp(2M) are spanned by the bilinears ˆ T α β = 1 2 {â α , ˆ b β } , ˆ P αβ = ˆ a α ˆ a β , ˆ K αβ = ˆ b α ˆ b β . (1.13)

div.p: Instead of working in terms of operators it is convenient to use the star-product operation in the algebra of polynomials of commuting variables a α and b

figure.trash: α (f ⋆ g)(a, b) = 1 π 2M f (a + u, b + t)g(a + s, b + v)e 2(sαt α −uαv α ) d M u d M t d M s d M v . (1.14)

div.p: The star-product defined this way, often called Moyal product, describes the product of symmetrized (i.e Weyl ordered) polynomials of oscillators in terms of symbols of operators. The integral is normalized in such a way that

figure.trash: 1 π 2M e 2(sαt α −uαv α ) d M u d M t d M s d M v = 1 , (1.15)

div.p: so that 1 is the unit element of the algebra. Eq.(1.14) defines the associative algebra with the defining relations [a α , b β ] ⋆ = δ α β , [a α , a β ] ⋆ = 0 , [b α , b β ] ⋆ = 0 (1.16) ([a, b] ⋆ = a ⋆ b − b ⋆ a). The star product realization of the generators of sp(2M) is

figure.trash: T α β = a α b β , P αβ = a α a β , K αβ = b α b β , (1.17) where the gl(M) generator T α β decomposes into the sl(M) " Lorentz " and o(1, 1) " dilatation " generators L α β = a α b β − 1 M δ α β a γ b γ , D = 1 2 a α b α . (1.18)

div.p: The bilinears of oscillators fulfil the commutation relations (1.4)-(1.9).

The embedding of the generalized AdS subalgebra into the conformal algebra sp(2M) is achieved by identification of the (generalized) AdS translations with the mixture of translations and special conformal transformations P

div.head: AdS αβ
div.p: = P αβ + λ 2 η αβγδ K γδ with some bilinear form η αβγδ . (Note that keeping the same number of translation generators we keep dimension of the generalized space-time intact). As argued in [1], η αβγδ has to have the factorized form: η αβγδ = V αγ V βδ , where V αβ is some nondegenerate antisymmetric form (thus requiring M to be even). In what follows the form V αβ will be used to raise and lower indices according to the rule A α = V βα A

figure.trash: β , A α = V αβ A β , V αβ V αγ = δ β γ . (1.19) Thus, the generalized AdS translations have the form P AdS αβ = P αβ + λ 2 V αγ V βδ K γδ = P αβ + λ 2 K αβ . (1.20) The commutation relations of P AdS αβ have the form [P AdS αβ , P AdS γδ ] = 2λ 2 (V βγ L AdS αδ + V βδ L AdS αγ + V αγ L AdS βδ + V αδ L AdS βγ ) , (1.21) where L AdS αβ = L
figure.figDesc: AdS βα are generators of the sp(M) subalgebra of gl M which leaves invariant the symplectic form V αβ . The full generalized AdS subalgebra is sp(M) ⊕
figure.trash: sp(M) ⊂ sp(2M). Its Lorentz subalgebra sp l (M) identifies with the diagonal sp(M) while AdS translations span sp(M) ⊕ sp(M)/sp l (M). Note that the generalized dS algebra obtained from (1.20) by virtue of the sign change λ 2 → −λ 2 is Sp(M, C) R . 1.2 Fock space and Sp(2M) covariant equations

div.p: The sp(2M) invariant equations of all massless fields in three and four dimensions are naturally described [8, 1] in terms of sections of the Fock fiber bundle over M M .
In other words, consider functions on M M taking values in the Fock module F

figure.trash: |Φ(b|X) = C(b|X) ⋆ |00| , (1.22) where C(b|X) is some " generating function " C(b|X) = ∞ m=0 1 m! c β 1 ...βm (X)b β 1 ...b βm (1.23) and |00| is the Fock vacuum defined by the relations a α ⋆ |00| = 0 , |00| ⋆ b α = 0 . (1.24) |00| can be realized as an element of the star-product algebra |00| = e −2aαb α . (1.25) Note that the Fock vacuum is the space-time constant projector d|00| = 0 , |00| ⋆ |00| = |00| , (1.26) where d is de Rahm differential d = dX αβ ∂ ∂X αβ , d 2 = 0. (1.27) As shown in [1]

div.p: the relevant flat space Sp(2M) covariant equation can be formulated in the form

figure.trash: d|Φ(b|X) − w 0 ⋆ |Φ(b|X) = 0 , (1.28) where w 0 = 1 2 dX αβ a α a β . (1.29)

div.p: That the equation (1.28) does indeed describe all conformal field equations in d = 3 and d = 4 was shown in [8] and [1] for the cases of M = 2 and M = 4, respectively.

In this paper we will consider the general case of any even M. It is worth to mention that the cases of M = 8, M = 16, and M = 32 were argued in [2] to correspond to conformal systems in d = 6, d = 10 and d = 11, respectively. The Fock fiber bundle realization of the higher spin equations guarantees generalized conformal symmetry of the system along with its infinite-dimensional higher spin extension. Actually, let w 0 be some 1-form, taking values in the higher spin algebra identified with the star product algebra (i.e., the algebra of regular functions of oscillators acting on the Fock module F )

figure.trash: w 0 (X) = ∞ m,n=0 1 m!n! w 0 β 1 ...βm α 1 ...αn (X)a α 1 ...a αn b β 1 ...b βm , (1.30) which satisfies the zero-curvature condition dw 0 = w 0 ⋆ ∧w 0 . (1.31) The equations (1.28), (1.31) are invariant under the gauge transformations δw 0 = dǫ − [w 0 , ǫ] ⋆ , (1.32) δ|Φ(b|X) = ǫ ⋆ |Φ(b|X) , (1.33) where ǫ(a, b|X

div.p: ) is an arbitrary infinitesimal gauge parameter. Any fixed vacuum solution w 0 of the equation (1.31) breaks the local higher spin symmetry to its stability subalgebra with the infinitesimal parameters ǫ 0 (a, b|X) satisfying the equation

figure.trash: dǫ 0 − [w 0 , ǫ 0 ] ⋆ = 0. (1.34) Consistency of this equation is guaranteed by (1.31). As a result, (1.34) admits locally a pure gauge solution w 0 (X) = −g −1 (X) ⋆ dg(X) , (1.35) where g(a, b|X) is some invertible element of the star-product algebra. The global symmetry parameters satisfying (1.34) then have the form ǫ 0 (X) = g −1 (X) ⋆ ξ ⋆ g(X) , (1.36)

div.p: where an arbitrary X-independent element ξ = ξ(a, b) of the star-product algebra describes parameters of the global higher spin symmetry which acts on the solutions of the equation (1.28) (for any given w 0 ). In particular, the sp(2M) subalgebra spanned by bilinears of oscillators is thus shown to be a symmetry of the equation (1.28).
Analogously one solves the equation (1.28) in the form

) plays a role of initial data. The meaning of this formula is that the Fock module |Φ(b|X 0 ) parametrises all combinations of the derivatives of the dynamical fields at X = X 0 which are allowed to be nonzero by the field equations. The formula (1.37) plays a role of the covariantized Taylor expansion reconstructing generic solution in terms of its derivatives at X = X 0 . Note that the Fock module F is not unitary because it decomposes into an infinite sum of finite-dimensional (tensor) representations of the generalized noncompact Lorentz algebra sl M (R). Nevertheless, the fact that initial data of the problem are formulated in terms of the Fock module F is closely related to the fact (see e.g. [3, 4]) that the collection of unitary massless representations corresponding to this dynamical system in d = 4 is described by the unitary Fock module U known as singleton representation of sp(8). (It is also well known that unitary representations of the 4d conformal algebra associated with massless fields admit Fock realization in terms of appropriate oscillators [10].) As shown in [8, 1], the modules U and F are related by some Bogolyubov transform. The formulae (1.35), (1.37) will play the key role in our analysis. They allow one to solve the equations of motion explicitly provided that the gauge function g(X) is found that corresponds to a chosen zero-curvature connection w 0 . This program for the flat connection (1.29) was accomplished in [1]. In this paper we will find a family of such gauge functions g(X) that all nonvanishing components of w 0 take values in the AdS subalgebra osp(L|M) ⊕ osp(L|M) of osp(2L|2M).

figure.trash: 2 Sp(M ) and star product

div.p: As argued in [1], the generalized AdS space is identified with Sp(M). Let us note that the generalized conformal group Sp(2M) does not act globally on Sp(M) analogously to the usual conformal group acting in the Minkowski space-time by Möbius transformations which have singularities. Recall that usual Minkowski space-time is the big cell of the compactified Minkowski space. Analogously, the generalized Minkowski space-time is the big cell in the compactified generalized space-time M M .
The universal covering space of Sp(M) can be thought of as a sort of deformation of the generalized Minkowski space-time being the big cell of M M .
The group Sp(M) is realized by the M

figure.trash: × M matrices U α β satisfying U α β U γ δ V αγ = V βδ , (2.1) where V αβ is some non-degenerate antisymmetric form V αβ = −V βα (M is even). The manifold Sp(M) is M (M +1) 2 dimensional. It can be described by local coordinates X αβ = X βα . The simplest parametrization is U α β = (exp(λX)) α β , (2.2)

div.p: where λ is inverse " radius " of Sp(M) introduced to compensate the space dimensionality of X αβ . Note that a particular value of λ = 0 is irrelevant unless there are some other dimensionful parameters in the theory (e.g., the gravitational constant).

figure.trash: The exponential in (2.2) is the matrix exponential of X α β = V γα X γβ . (2.3)

div.p: It is elementary to see that the parametrization (2.2) solves the group equation (2.1). The exponential parametrization (2.2) provides the universal covering space [11]

figure.trash: of Sp(M) (metaplectic group Mp(M)) topologically equivalent to R M (M +1) 2 , the big cell of M M . Sp(M) is invariant under the action of Sp(M) × Sp(M) generated by left and right actions of Sp(M) on itself. Using the oscillator realization of sp(M)⊕sp(M) ⊂ sp(2M) we can set w 0 (X) = ω αβ (X)a α b β + h αβ (X)(a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , (2.4) where the " Lorentz connection " ω αβ (X) and the " frame " h αβ (X) have the form ω αβ = − 1 2 d(U −1 ) α γ U γβ + dU α γ (U −1 ) γβ , (2.5) h αβ = 1 4λ dU α γ (U −1 ) γβ − d(U −1 ) α γ U γβ , (2.6) which guarantees that w 0 satisfies (1.31). In the exponential parametrization (2.2) one gets ω αβ = λ 2 dX µν   1 0 exp(λXt) µβ exp(λXt) να dt − 0 −1 exp(λXt) µβ exp(λXt) να dt   , (2.7) h αβ = 1 4 dX µν 1 −1 exp(λXt) µβ exp(λXt) να dt , (2.8) where we used the identity δe A = 1 0 e At δAe A(1−t

div.p: ) dt valid for an arbitrary matrix A.
As expected, in the flat limit λ → 0 one recovers (1.29). Let us now present the star product pure gauge form (

figure.trash: 1.35) of the connection (2.4)-(2.6). The final result is g = 1 det ch λX 2 exp − 1 λ th λX 2 αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , (2.9) g −1 = 1 det ch λX 2 exp 1 λ th λX 2 αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) . (2.10)

div.p: This formula is derived as follows. Let sp(M) be realized in terms of bilinears of oscillators α α satisfying the commutation relations [α α , α β ] * = −2V αβ ,

figure.trash: (2.11) with the star-product (f * g)(α) = 1 (2π) M f (α + u)g(α + v)e uαv α d M u d M v . (2.12) Consider star-product algebra elements g 1 and g 2 of the form g 1 = r 1 e 1 2 f αβ 1 ααα β , g 2 = r 2 e 1 2 f αβ 2 ααα β . (2.13) with some α-independent r 1 , r 2 , f αβ 1 and f αβ 2 . Elementary evaluation of the Gaussian integrals shows that g 1,2 = g 1 * g 2 = r 1,2 e 1 2 (f 1 @BULLETf 2 ) αβ ααα β , (2.14) where r 1,2 = r 1 r 2 det f 1 f 2 + 1 (2.15) and f 1 • f 2 = 1 1 + f 2 f 1 (1 + f 2 ) − 1 1 + f 1 f 2 (1 − f 1 ) (2.16) (with the usual matrix multiplication on the right hand side: AB → A α γ B γ β , 1 A B → (A −1 ) α γ B γ β ). Let us look for a map g(U) = r(U)e 1 2 f αβ (U )ααα β (2.17) of Sp(M) into the star-product algebra, such that g(U 1 ) * g(U 2 ) = g(U 1 U 2 ) = r(U 1 U 2 )e 1 2 f αβ (U 1 U 2 )ααα β . (2.18) Equivalently, one can use the inverse map U(f ) requiring U(f 1 )U(f 2 ) = U(f 1 • f 2 ) . (2.19) As shown in appendix, the multiplication law (2.16) requires U αβ (f ) = 1 + f 1 − f αβ . (2.20) The inverse formula is analogous f αβ (U) = U − 1 1 + U αβ . (2.21) The normalization factor is r(U) = 2 M 2 det U + 1 . (2.22) To derive (2.9) it remains to use (2.2) and to observe that the two sp(M) subalgebras of sp(2M) are generated by the two mutually commuting sets of oscillators α ± α = a α √ λ ± √ λV βα b β = 1 √ λ (a α ± λb α ) , (2.23) satisfying the commutation relations [α ± α , α ± β ] * = ±2V αβ . (2.24) The map (2.20) has a number of interesting properties. In particular, U −1 (f ) = U(−f ) , (2.25) U(f ) = −U −1 (−f −1 ) . (2.26) The property (2.25

div.p: ) is a consequense of the elementary fact (see e.g. [12]) that the star product (

figure.trash: 2.12) admits an antiautomorphism ρ(g(α)) = g(iα), i.e. ρ(g 1 ) * ρ(g 2 ) = ρ(g 2 * g 1 ). From (2.17) it follows that ρ(U(f )) = U(−f ). The natural group antiautomorphism is ρ(U) = U −1 . The formula (2.25

div.p: ) identifies the antiautomorphism ρ in the star product algebra with that of the group Sp(M). The formula (2.26) is more interesting. It does not have a global interpretation within Sp(M) being singular at degenerate f αβ (in particular for f αβ = 0 and, therefore, U = I). However, these maps are expected to have global meaning in M M where one can define inversion by analogy with the flat case considered in [2]

figure.figDesc: The formula (2.26) implies that these two definitions are consistent with each other. Note that inversion defined this way maps unit element of Sp(M) to the central element −I which does not belong to the connected component of unity P Sp(M) ⊂ Sp(M).

div.head: Arbitrary coordinates
div.p: The gauge function (2.9) corresponds to the exponential realization of Sp(M), thus yielding global coordinates which cover the metaplectic group Mp(M). Our formalism allows one to write down explicit form of vacuum gauge connections (Cartan forms) in arbitrary coordinates, however. Indeed, let us consider a gauge function of the form

figure.trash: g = det 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) exp − f (X) αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , g −1 = det 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) exp f (X) αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , (3.1) where f αβ (X) = f
figure.figDesc: βα (X) is an arbitrary function of matrix coordinates X αβ . The zero-curvature connection (1.35) can be written in the form

p.formula: w 0 = −g(−f ) ⋆ dX αβ ∂f γλ 1 ∂X αβ ∂ ∂f γλ 1 g(f 1 ) f 1 =f . (3.2)

div.p: Direct computation leads to the expressions for the " Lorentz connection " and

p.formula: " frame " h αβ = dX ρσ 1 1 − λ 2 f 2 αγ ∂f γ λ ∂X ρσ − λ 2 f γ µ ∂f µ ν ∂X ρσ f ν λ 1 1 − λ 2 f 2 λ β , (3.3) ω αβ = 2λ 2 dX ρσ 1 1 − λ 2 f 2 αγ ∂f γ µ ∂X ρσ f µ λ − f γ µ ∂f µ λ ∂X ρσ 1 1 − λ 2 f 2 λ β . (3.4)

div.p: Note that from these formulae it follows that

p.formula: ω αβ = 2h αγ f γ β − 2f αγ h γ β + λ 2 f αγ ω γ λ f λ β . (3.5)

figure.figDesc: An arbitrary function f αβ (X) parametrizes various coordinate choices in Sp(M). A relationship with the coordinates of the exponential parametrization obviously is
figure.trash: f ( ˜ X) = 1 λ th λX 2 (3.6) which implies locally sh λX 2 = λf ( ˜ X) 1 − λ 2 f 2 ( ˜ X) , ch λX 2 = 1 1 − λ 2 f 2 ( ˜ X) . (3.7) The formulae (3.3) and (3.4

figure.figDesc: ) thus provide a representation for Cartan forms in arbitrary coordinates associated with one or another function f αβ (X). Consider now a few particular examples. Let f αβ (X) be of the form
figure.trash: f αβ (X) = φ(det X)X αβ . (3.8) The corresponding connections are h αβ = φ · 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 αγ (dX γ λ − λ 2 φ 2 X γ µ dX µ ν X ν λ ) 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 λ β + + ˜ φ · dX ρσ (X −1 ) ρσ X 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 αβ , (3.9) ω αβ = 2λ 2 φ 2 · 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 αγ (dX γ µ X µ λ − X γ µ dX µ λ ) 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 λ β , (3.10) where φ = ∂φ ∂ ln det X . (3.11) Another useful example results from f ± αβ (X) = X 1 ∓ √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 αβ . (3.12) The corresponding gauge function is g ± = det 1 + λX ± √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 λX exp   − X 1 ∓ √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β )   . (3.13)

figure.figDesc: In these " stereographic " coordinates the " frame " gets the following simple form

p.formula: h αβ = 1 2 1 √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 αγ dX γ λ 1 √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 λ β . (3.14)

div.p: Let us now compare this formula with those obtained in [8, 9] to describe massless fields in AdS 3 (M = 2) and AdS 4 (M = 4).

figure.figDesc: Let us first consider the case M = 2. Using for example g
figure.trash: + , from (3.13) one obtains g = 2 √ z 1 + √ z exp − 1 1 + √ z x αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , (3.15) g −1 = 2 √ z 1 + √ z exp 1 1 + √ z x αβ (a α a β + λ 2 b α b β ) , (3.16) where z = 1 + 1 2 λ 2 x αβ x αβ . The " frame " and the " Lorentz connection " are h αβ = 1 2z dx αβ , ω αβ = 1 2z (dx α γ x γβ + dx β γ x γα ). (3.17)

div.p: To derive this result, which reproduces that of [8], we used a simple fact that, when M = 2, any antisymmetric matrix is proportional to V αβ and, therefore, any polynomial of matrix coordinates P (x) αβ decomposes into a combination of its symmetric part P S (x µν x µν )x αβ and antisymmetric part P A (x µν x µν )V αβ . From (3.17) it follows that the metric tensor is

p.formula: g mn = 1 2 h αβ,n h αβ ,m = 1 4 η mn (1 + λ 2 x k x k ) 2 , (3.18) where x n = σ n αβ x αβ , x αβ = 1 2 σ αβ n x n , (3.19)

div.p: and σ n αβ is a set of basis symmetric real matrices normalized to satisfy σ n αβ σ mαβ = 2η mn , (3.20) where η mn is the flat Minkowski metric.
To consider the 4d case we embed AdS 4 space-time into M 4 as follows

figure.figDesc: β are local AdS 4 coordinates which can be expressed via the vector coordinates x n (n = 0 . . . 3) with the aid of Pauli matrices

p.formula: σ n ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = (I, σ 1 ¯ α ˙ ¯ β . . . σ 3 ¯ α ˙ ¯ β ) as x n = σ n ¯ α ˙ ¯ β x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β , x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = 1 2 x n σ n ¯ α ˙ ¯ β , σ n ¯ α ˙ ¯ β σ m ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = 2η mn . (3.22)

div.p: The gauge function and gravitational fields resulting from (

figure.trash: 3.13) and (3.14) are g = 2 √ z 1 + √ z 2 exp − 1 1 + √ z x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β (a ¯ α a ˙ ¯ β + λ 2 b ¯ α b ˙ ¯ β ) , (3.23) h ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = 1 2z dx ¯ α ˙ ¯ β , (3.24) ω ¯ α ¯ β = 1 2z (dx ¯ α ˙ ¯ γ x¯ β ˙ ¯ γ + dx¯ β ˙ ¯ γ x ¯ α ˙ ¯ γ ) , ¯ ω ˙ ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = 1 2z (dx ¯ γ ˙ ¯ α x ¯ γ ˙ ¯ β + dx ¯ γ ˙ ¯ β x ¯ γ ˙ ¯ α ) , (3.25) where z = 1 + 1 2 λ 2 x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β = 1 + λ 2 x n x n . These AdS 4

div.p: gravitational fields coincide with those found in [9]

Having fixed some vacuum solution w 0 of (1.31), the local higher spin symmetry is broken down to the global one with the parameter ǫ 0 (a, b|X) satisfying (1.34). Once the vacuum solution w 0 is fixed in the pure gauge form (1.35) with some gauge function g, it is easy to find the gauge parameter ǫ 0 (a, b|X) of the leftover global symmetry. Indeed let the generating parameter ξ(a, b; µ, η) in (1.36) be of the form ξ = ξ 0 exp(a α µ α − b α η α ) , (4.1) where ξ 0 is an infinitesimal constant while µ α and η α are constant parameters. An arbitrary symmetry with star-product polynomial parameters can be obtained via differentiation of ξ with respect to µ α and η α .

figure.trash: Substitution of (2.9) into (1.36) gives ǫ 0 (a, b; µ, η|X) = g −1 ⋆ ξ ⋆ g = ξ 0 exp(a α ˆ µ α − b α ˆ η α ) , (4.2) where ˆ µ α = ch(λX) αβ µ β − sh(λX) αβ λ η β , ˆ η α = ch(λX) αβ η β − λ · sh(λX) αβ µ β . (4.3) According to (3.7), in the arbitrary coordinates associated with the function f αβ (X) of section 3, we have ˆ µ α = 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) α β µ β − 2f (X) 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) α β η β , (4.4) ˆ η α = 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) α β η β − λ 2 2f (X) 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) α β µ β . (4.5) The global symmetry transformation of the higher spin generating function δ|Φ(b|X) ≡ ǫ 0 ⋆ |Φ(b|X) = ξ 0 exp(−ˆ η α ˆ µ α ) · C(b + ˆ µ|X) ⋆ |00| (4.6) implies δC(b|X) = ξ 0 C(b + ˆ µ|X) exp 1 2 ˆ η α ˆ µ α − b α ˆ η α . (4.7) The dynamical fields are associated with the scalar c(X) = C(0|X) and svector c α (X) = ∂ ∂b α C(b|X) b=0

div.p: in the expansion (1.23). (All other fields in C(b|X) are expressed via derivatives of the dynamical fields [1].) Their transformation laws are

figure.trash: δc(X) = ξ 0 C(ˆ µ|X) exp( 1 2 ˆ η α ˆ µ α ) , (4.8) δc α (X) = ξ 0 ∂ ∂b α C(b + ˆ µ|X) b=0 − ˆ η α C(ˆ µ|X) exp( 1 2 ˆ η α ˆ µ α ) . (4.9)

div.p: Differentiating over the parameters µ α and η α and setting them then equal to zero one obtains explicit expressions for the higher spin symmetry transformations associated with any symmetry parameters ǫ 0 (a, b|X) polynomial in the oscillators a and b.
In particular, the transformation law with the parameters bilinear in the oscillators reproduces the Sp(2M) generalized conformal transformations in the generalized AdS space-time Sp(M).

div.head: Light-like solutions
div.p: Once the gauge function g is known one solves the system of free field equation (1.28) for all massless fields via (1.37). Let us consider basis light-like solutions generated by the initial data of the form

figure.trash: C(b|0) = C 0 exp(κ α b α ) , (5.1)

div.p: where C 0 is an arbitrary constant and κ α is some space-time constant spinor. According to (1.22) the Fock representation of the initial data has the form

figure.trash: |Φ(b|0) = C 0 exp(κ α b α ) ⋆ |00|. (5.2) So the dynamical problem is solved by |Φ(b|X) = g −1 (X) ⋆ |Φ(b|0) = C 0 det ch λX 2 e 1 λ (th λX 2 ) αβ (aαa β +λ 2 bαb β ) ⋆ e καb α ⋆ e −2aαb α . (5.3) Elementary evaluation of Gaussian integrals gives the following result C(b|X) = C 0 det chλX exp t αβ (λ 2 b α b β + κ α κ β ) + p β α κ α b β , (5.4) where we use notations t α β = th(λX) 2λ α β , p α β = (ch −1 (λX)) α β , (5.5) equivalent by virtue of (3.7) to t α β = f (X) 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) α β , p α β = 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) α β . (5.6)

div.p: Let us stress that, according to [1, 2], for the particular case of M = 4 the obtained expressions describe solutions of massless equations for all spins in AdS 4 , constructed in [9]. Using (3.23), these solutions take the form

figure.trash: C(b|x) = z exp x ¯ α ˙ ¯ β 2 (κ ¯ α κ ˙ ¯ β + λ 2 b ¯ α b ˙ ¯ β ) + √ zκ α b α . (5.7)

div.p: For the case of M = 2 we get solutions of the AdS 3 massless equations discussed in [8] of the form

figure.trash: C(b|x) = √ z exp x αβ 2 (κ α κ β + λ 2 b α b β ) + √ zκ α b α . (5.8) Here we make use of the gauge function (3.15). For the dynamical fields we obtain c(X) = C 0 det 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) exp(t αβ κ α κ β ) , (5.9) c α (X) = C 0 det 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) p α β κ β exp (t αβ κ α κ β ) . (5.10) Substitution of ǫ 0 into (1.33) gives the global higher spin symmetry transformation of the solution (5.3) δC(b|X) = C 0 ξ 0 det 1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) 1 + λ 2 f 2 (X) exp t αβ λ 2 (b α + ˆ µ α )(b β + ˆ µ β ) + t αβ κ α κ β + p β α κ α (b β + ˆ µ β ) − ˆ η α (b α + 1 2 ˆ µ α ) . (5.11) The flat limit λ → 0 gives δC(b|X) = C 0 ξ 0 exp 1 2 X αβ (κ α κ β − 2κ α η β + η α η β ) + +b α (κ α − η α ) + κ α µ α + 1 2 µ α η α . (5.12)
figure.figDesc: For the dynamical fields we get the plane wave solutions
figure.trash: c plane (X) = C 0 e 1 2 X αβ κ α κ β , c plane α (X) = C 0 κ α e 1 2 X αβ κ α κ β , (5.13) with the twistorial " wave vector " K αβ = 1 2

div.p: The solution deformed to the AdS case is not strictly speaking plane wave. However it is " conformally plane wave " in the sense that it has still leftover generalized conformal invariances identified with such global symmetry transformations that δ ǫ 0 |Φ(b|X) = 0 . (5.14) It is easy to see using (4.2) that this condition is solved by any parameter of the form ξ = f (a, b) ⋆ (ρ α a α ) , (5.15) where ρ is an arbitrary parameter such that ρ α κ α = 0 and f (a, b) is an arbitrary function. Indeed, according to (

div.head: Superextension
div.p: The star-product formalism we use admits a straightforward generalization to the supersymmetric case associated with OSp(L|2M) where L is an arbitrary integer.

To describe osp(L|2M) superalgebra let us introduce the Clifford elements ψ i (i = 1 . . . L) satisfying the anticommutation relations {ψ i , ψ j } * = η ij , (6.1) where η ij = η ji is some non-degenerate symmetric form. The Clifford star-product in (6.1) is defined (see, e.g., [12]) according to

figure.trash: (f * g)(ψ) = 1 2 L f (ψ + φ)g(ψ + χ)e −2χ i φ i d L φd L χ , (6.2) where χ i and φ i are anticommuting variables. The supercharges Q iα = a α ψ i , S α i = b α ψ i (6.3) satisfy {Q iα , Q iβ } * = η ij P αβ , {S α i , S β j } * = η ij K αβ . (6.4)

div.p: Let the Grassmann odd coordinates θ iα be associated with the Q-supergenerators. It is convenient to require the differential dθ iα to anticommute to dX αβ and θ iα . It is easy to see [1] that the gauge function g = e −X αβ aαa β −θ iα aαψ i

figure.trash: (6.5) reproduces the flat superspace vacuum 1-form w 0 = dX αβ + 1 2 dθ iα θ i β P αβ + dθ iα Q iα . (6.6) The left Fock module |Φ(b, ψ + |X, θ) satisfies the osp(L|2M) supersymmetric equation (d − w 0 ) ⋆ |Φ(b, ψ + |X, θ) = 0 , (6.7) where the supersymmetric Fock vacuum |00| in addition to (1.26) is annihilated by the 1 2 L (in case of even L) or 1 2

div.p: (L−1) (in case of odd L) annihilation Clifford elements ψ − and, when L is odd, it is an eigenvector of the central element Ψ L = ψ 1 . . . ψ L Ψ L ⋆ |00| = ±|00| .

Let us now consider free field dynamics in the generalized AdS superspace. The corresponding supersymmetry algebra is osp(L, M)⊕osp(L, M) while the superspace is osp(L, M). To describe background fields (i.e., Cartan forms) in such a space we follow the same procedure as for Sp(M).

figure.figDesc: The OSp(L|M) supergroup is realized by (M + L) × (M + L) matrices U A B , where A = (α, i)(α = 1 . . . M, i = 1 . . . L), satisfying the group condition
figure.trash: U A B U C D Ω AC = Ω BD , (6.8) where Ω AB = −(−1) π A π B Ω BA and π A = 1 , A = i 0 , A = α .

figure.figDesc: It can be described by the local supercoordinates X AB = (−1) π A π B X BA with the aid of the exponential parametrization
figure.trash: U A B = exp(λX) A B . (6.9)

div.p: Let us introduce the super-oscillators a A , b A satisfying the (anti)commutation rela- tions a A ⋆ b B − (−1) π A π B b B ⋆ a A = δ A B , (6.10) with respect to the star-product (f ⋆ g)(a, b|X) = 1 2 2L π M f (a+ u, b+ t)g(a+ s, b+ v)e 2(t A s A −v A u A ) dudtdsdv , (6.11) where the statistics of the integration variables is defined according to u A u B = (−1) π A π B u B u A .
The integration measure is chosen so that 1 is the unit element of the star-product algebra (6.11).
Using the oscillator realization of osp(L|M) ⊕ osp(L|M) ⊂ osp(2L|2M) we can set w 0 = ω AB a B b A + h AB (a B a A + λ 2 b B b A ) . (6.12)
The analysis analogous to that of section 2 shows that the gauge function

figure.trash: g = sdet1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) exp − f AB (X)(a B a A + λ 2 b B b A ) (6.13) provides the " Lorentz connection " ω AB and the " frame " h AB of the form ω AB = 1 2 (dU A C (U −1 ) CB + d(U −1 ) A C U CB ) , (6.14) h AB = 1 4λ (dU A C (U −1 ) CB − d(U −1 ) A C U CB ) , (6.15) where U A B = 1 + λf (X) 1 − λf (X) A B . (6.16) The relationship between h AB and ω AB is analogous to (3.5) ω AB = 2h A C f CB − 2f A C h CB + λ 2 f A C ω C D f DB . (6.17)
figure.figDesc: Here is the list of the gauge functions and corresponding Cartan forms in different coordinates. 1. The exponential parametrization (6.9)
figure.trash: g = 1 sdetch λX 2 exp − th λX 2 AB (a B a A + λ 2 b B b A ) , (6.18) ω AB = λ 2 1 0 exp(λXt) A C dX C D exp(λXt) DB dt− 0 −1 exp(λXt) A C dX C D exp(λXt) DB dt (6.19) h AB = 1 4 1 −1 exp(λXt) A C dX C D exp(λXt) DB dt (6.20) 2. f AB = φ(sdetX)X AB g = sdet1 − λ 2 φ 2 · X 2 exp − φX AB (a B a A + λ 2 b B b A ) , (6.21) h AB = φ · 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 A C (dX C D − λ 2 φ 2 X C M dX M N X N D ) 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 DB − − ˜ φ · X 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 AB (X −1 ) M N dX N M , ω AB = 2λ 2 φ 2 · 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 A C (dX C M X M D − X C M dX M D ) 1 1 − λ 2 φ 2 X 2 DB , (6.22) where φ = ∂φ ∂ ln sdetX . (6.23) 3. The " stereographic " coordinates f AB (X) = X 1∓ √ 1−λ 2 X 2 AB g ± = sdet1 − λ 2 f 2 (X) exp − X 1 ∓ √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 AB (a B a A + λ 2 b B b A ) , (6.24) h AB = 1 2 1 √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 A C dX C D 1 √ 1 − λ 2 X 2 DB . (6.25)

figure.figDesc: In the supersymmetric case, the global higher spin symmetry transformation law for the generating function C(b|X) with respect to infinitesimal parameter
figure.trash: ξ = ξ 0 exp(µ A a A − b A η A ) is analogous to (4.7) δC(b|X) = C(b + ˆ µ|X) exp − (b A + 1 2 ˆ µ A )ˆ η A , (6.26) where ˆ µ A = ch(λX) AB µ B − sh(λX) AB λ η B , ˆ η A = ch(λX) AB η B −λ·sh(λX) AB µ B . (6.27)

div.p: It is straightforward to extend the rest of the analysis to the dynamics in the generalized superspace. Also, having found left invariant forms it is elementary to write down world-line particle actions (see e.g., [4, 5, 1] for more details and references). The form of the world-line particle Lagrangian suggested in [1]

figure.trash: L = ˙ X AB w 0AB (a, b|X) + a A ˙ b A , (6.28) where dX AB w 0AB (a, b|X) = w 0

div.p: (a, b|X) is the vacuum 1-form satisfying the zerocurvature equation (1.31) and dot denotes the derivative with respect to the world line parameter. Applying the Stokes theorem and using (1.31) the particle action (6.28) can be rewritten in the string form as an integral over a two-dimensional surface bounded by a particle trajectory and parameterized by σ

figure.trash: l S = Σ 2 (w 0 (a, b|X) ⋆ ∧w 0 (a, b|X) + da A ∧ db A + +(da A ∂ ∂a A + db A ∂ ∂b A ) ∧ w 0 (a, b|X)) , (6.29) where the pullback is defined as usual w 0 (a, b|X) = dσ l ∂X AB ∂σ l w 0AB (a, b|X), da A = dσ l ∂a A ∂σ l , db A = dσ l ∂b A ∂σ l . (6.30)

div.p: The problem of calculating Cartan superforms in osp(1|2M) superspace was considered in [5] where a particular parametrization was found with bosonic Cartan forms being at most bilinear in fermionic coordinates. Note that the star-product algebra formalism simplifies some of the computational problems being reduced to evaluation of elementary Gaussian integrals.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: It is demonstrated how the star-product algebra formalism can be applied to the calculation of the vacuum of fields of the generalized AdS space associated with sp(M) ⊕ sp(M) subalgebra of the recently proposed in [2] generalized conformal symmetry Sp(2M). The method is universal working equally well for the supersymmetric case of OSp(L, M) with any M and L. The formalism of star-product algebra is shown to be very efficient for solving free field equations in non-trivial (generalized conformally flat) geometries in M M and calculating Cartan forms in arbitrary coordinates. Hopefully it may have applications to formulations of world line (super)particle dynamics as well as (super)string actions in M theory back- grounds.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: This research was supported in part by INTAS, Grant No.00-1-254, the RFBR Grant No.02-02-17067 and the RFBR Grant No.00-15-96566.

div.head: A Appendix
div.p: Let us prove that the formula

figure.trash: g(U) = 2 M 2 det U + 1 exp 1 2 U − 1 U + 1 αβ α α α β (A.1
figure.figDesc: ) respects the group multiplication law of Sp(M), i.e. that the formula (2.20) solves the equation (2.19). Let us look for U(f ) in the form
figure.trash: U(f ) = ∞ n=0 a n f n , (A.2) where a n are some coefficients. Hence U(f 1 )U(f 2 ) = ∞ m,n=0 a m a n f m 1 f n 2 .

div.p: Since this expression contains all f 1 on the left side, and f 2 on the right, we have to find such a function U(f ) that U(f 1 • f 2 ) contains f 1 and f 2 in the correct order. We have
All terms of wrong order must vanish. The analysis of a few first terms of U(f 1 • f 2 ) gives a hint that the coefficients are: a n = {a 0 , a, a, a, ...}, i.e.

figure.trash: U(f ) = a 0 − a + a 1 − f . (A.4) The substitution of U(f ) into the equation U 2 (f ) = U(f • f ) fixes a 0 = 1, a = 2 so that U(f ) = 1 + f 1 − f . (A.5)

div.p: To prove that the obtained solution satisfies the equation (2.19) one has to check the identity

figure.trash: (1 + f 1 • f 2 ) 1 − f 2 1 + f 2 = (1 − f 1 • f 2 ) 1 + f 1 1 − f 1 (A.6) equivalent to the relation {1 + ∞ n=0 (−1) n ((f 2 f 1 ) n (1 + f 2 ) − (f 1 f 2 ) n (1 − f 1 ))}(1 + 2 ∞ m=1 (−1) m f m 2 ) = {1 − ∞ n=0 (−1) n ((f 2 f 1 ) n (1 + f 2 ) − (f 1 f 2 ) n (1 − f 1 ))}(1 + 2 ∞ m=1 f m 1 ) , (A.7) which is elementary to check. The normalization factor solves the equation r(U 1 )r(U 2 ) det f 1 f 2 + 1 = r(U 1 U 2 ) , (A.8) which is obviously true after the substitution (2.20) 2 M 2 det U 1 + 1 · 2 M 2 det U 2 + 1 · 1 det U 1 −1 U 1 +1 U 2 −1 U 2 +1 + 1 = 2 M 2 det U 1 U 2 + 1 . (A.9)
figure.figDesc: This completes the proof of eq. (2.20). The proof for the supersymmetric case is analogous.
